We don't often get visitors, not humans like this. Most fear the fire, the power. This one, though? He stared at me with earnest, unblinking eyes, a recorder clutched in his hand.

"Please, –æ–≥–Ω–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –¥—Ä—É–≥," he begged, "tell me your story. The ancient dragons, the legends, the lost cities."

His words tumbled out in rapidfire, a mess of unfamiliar syllables. I could understand the meaning, though, woven through the strange sounds on the wind. He wanted history, he wanted tales spun from flame and shadow.

I pulled my worn leather jacket tighter around myself, the fabric a stark contrast to the linen tunics and hemp trousers of the people passing by. I was in mainland Russia, the year 1895, a far cry from the sleek glass skyscrapers and digital hum of my own time.

I'd been practicing my Russian, gleaned from dusty textbooks and grainy archival footage, for months. Now, faced with an actual conversation, my tongue felt heavy and clumsy.
